etymologies: Middle English (in seal (sense 2 of the noun)): from Old French seel (noun), seeler (verb), from Latin sigillum ‘small picture’, diminutive of signum ‘a sign’

definitions: a device or substance that is used to join two things together so as to prevent them from coming apart or to prevent anything from passing between them

examples.text: blue smoke from the exhaust suggests worn valve seals

shortDefinitions: device or substance that is used to join two things together so as to prevent them coming apart or to prevent anything passing between them

definitions: the state or fact of being joined or rendered impervious with a seal

examples.text: many fittings have tapered threads for a better seal

shortDefinitions: state or fact of being joined or rendered impervious with seal

definitions: the water standing in the trap of a drain to prevent sewer gas from backing up through the drain, considered in terms of its depth

examples.text: for most domestic applications, a 75 mm seal is required

shortDefinitions: water standing in trap of drain to prevent foul air from rising

definitions: a piece of wax, lead, or other material with an individual design stamped into it, attached to a document to show that it has come from the person who claims to have issued it.
shortDefinitions: piece of wax, lead, or other material with individual design stamped into it, attached to document as guarantee of authenticity

definitions: a design resembling a seal embossed in paper as a guarantee of authenticity.
shortDefinitions: design resembling seal embossed in paper as guarantee of authenticity

definitions: an engraved device used for stamping a design that authenticates a document.
shortDefinitions: engraved device used for stamping seal

definitions: a thing regarded as a confirmation or guarantee of something

examples.text: the International Monetary Fund is likely to give a seal of approval to the Mexican plan

shortDefinitions: thing regarded as confirmation or guarantee of something

definitions: the obligation on a priest not to divulge anything said during confession

examples.text: I was told under the seal

shortDefinitions: obligation on priest not to divulge anything said during confession

examples.text: he folded it, sealed the envelope, and walked to the mailbox

definitions: apply a nonporous coating to (a surface) to make it impervious

examples.text: seal the finish with a satin varnish

definitions: fry (food) briefly in hot fat to prevent it from losing too much of its moisture during subsequent cooking

examples.text: heat the oil and seal the lamb on both sides

shortDefinitions: fry food briefly at high temperature

definitions: conclude, establish, or secure (something) definitively, excluding the possibility of reversal or loss

examples.text: to seal the deal he offered Thornton a place on the board of the nascent company

shortDefinitions: conclude, establish, or secure something definitively

definitions: fix a piece of wax or lead stamped with a design to (a document) to authenticate it.
shortDefinitions: fix piece of wax or lead stamped with design

etymologies: Old English seolh, of Germanic origin

definitions: a fish-eating aquatic mammal with a streamlined body and feet developed as flippers, that returns to land to breed or rest.

notes.text: Families Phocidae (the true seals) and Otariidae (the eared seals, including the fur seals and sea lions). The latter have external ear flaps and are able to sit upright, and the males are much larger than the females

shortDefinitions: fish-eating aquatic mammal with streamlined body and feet developed as flippers
